user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14 is: The Standard Library function memcmp shall not be used to compare null terminated strings.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_connection_set_cork_state_:
```c
bool
MHD_connection_set_cork_state_ (struct MHD_Connection *connection,
                                bool cork_state)
{
#if defined(MHD_TCP_CORK_NOPUSH)
  const MHD_SCKT_OPT_BOOL_ off_val = 0;
  const MHD_SCKT_OPT_BOOL_ on_val = 1;
  int err_code;

  if (_MHD_YES == connection->is_nonip)
    return false;
  if (0 == setsockopt (connection->socket_fd,
                       IPPROTO_TCP,
                       MHD_TCP_CORK_NOPUSH,
                       (const void *) (cork_state ? &on_val : &off_val),
                       sizeof (off_val)))
  {
    connection->sk_corked = cork_state;
    return true;
  }

  err_code = MHD_socket_get_error_ ();
  if (MHD_SCKT_ERR_IS_ (err_code, MHD_SCKT_EINVAL_) ||
      MHD_SCKT_ERR_IS_ (err_code, MHD_SCKT_ENOPROTOOPT_) ||
      MHD_SCKT_ERR_IS_ (err_code, MHD_SCKT_ENOTSOCK_))
  {
    if (_MHD_UNKNOWN == connection->is_nonip)
      connection->is_nonip = _MHD_YES;
#ifdef HAVE_MESSAGES
    else
    {
      MHD_DLOG (connection->daemon,
                _ ("Setting %s option to %s state failed "
                   "for TCP/IP socket %d: %s\n"),
#ifdef TCP_CORK
                "TCP_CORK",
#else  /* ! TCP_CORK */
                "TCP_NOPUSH",
#endif /* ! TCP_CORK */
                cork_state ? _ ("ON") : _ ("OFF"),
                (int) connection->socket_fd,
                MHD_socket_strerr_ (err_code));
    }
#endif /* HAVE_MESSAGES */
  }
#ifdef HAVE_MESSAGES
  else
  {
    MHD_DLOG (connection->daemon,
              _ ("Setting %s option to %s state failed: %s\n"),
#ifdef TCP_CORK
              "TCP_CORK",
#else  /* ! TCP_CORK */
              "TCP_NOPUSH",
#endif /* ! TCP_CORK */
              cork_state ? _ ("ON") : _ ("OFF"),
              MHD_socket_strerr_ (err_code));
  }
#endif /* HAVE_MESSAGES */

#else  /* ! MHD_TCP_CORK_NOPUSH */
  (void) connection; (void) cork_state; /* Mute compiler warnings. */
#endif /* ! MHD_TCP_CORK_NOPUSH */
  return false;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I inspected the provided function and found no uses of the Standard Library function memcmp. There are no explicit byte-wise comparisons of null-terminated strings, no calls to memcmp, and no code that emulates memcmp (no manual loops comparing bytes). The operations present are: integer constants and assignments (on_val/off_val), setsockopt calls passing addresses of integer values, integer error-code checks via macros (MHD_SCKT_ERR_IS_), and logging calls that pass string literals or strings returned from MHD_socket_strerr_. The cast to (const void *) in setsockopt passes pointers to integer values, not C strings. Conditional compilation macros produce string literals for logging (e.g. "TCP_CORK"/"TCP_NOPUSH") but these literals are not compared via memcmp in this fragment. Therefore there are no fragments in this code that need investigation for Rule 21.14 (memcmp used to compare null-terminated strings). If you want, I can also search other source files or macro definitions (e.g. definitions of MHD_SCKT_ERR_IS_ or MHD_socket_strerr_) for any memcmp usage.
